title: Integral Yoga
description: A progressive exploration of the core tenets, practices, and transformative aims of Integral Yoga as envisioned by Sri Aurobindo and The Mother.

paragraphs.summary: The inherent human seeking for a greater Truth, Light, Bliss, and Immortality beyond ordinary existence.
The fundamental state of limited consciousness, separation from the Divine, and its consequences: suffering, falsehood, and death.
Not merely individual liberation, but the transformation of human nature and the establishment of a divine life in a divine body upon Earth.
The nature of the ultimate Reality: Sat (Existence), Chit (Consciousness-Force), Ananda (Bliss).
The process by which the Divine Consciousness involves or veils itself in successive gradations, culminating in the apparent inconscience of Matter.
The progressive emergence and unfolding of the involved Consciousness in Matter, through life and mind, towards its divine origin.
The ultimate, transcendent and immanent Reality; the Conscious Being who is the origin, support, and aim of all existence.
Not merely thought, but a fundamental reality and power (Chit-Tapas) that can be concentrated, expanded, and transformed.
The Divine's plenary self-knowledge and world-knowledge; a Truth-Consciousness that can directly manifest the Divine in life.
The instrumental nature composed of the ordinary mental, vital, and physical consciousness, typically governed by ignorance and ego.
The larger, truer mental, vital, and subtle-physical consciousness behind the surface, open to universal forces and higher planes.
The Chaitya Purusha, the soul-spark of the Divine within, growing through experiences and guiding the being towards the Divine.
The Jivatman, the true individual Self, eternally one with the Transcendent, presiding over the psychic being's evolution.
The sense of a separate self, a formation of nature based on ignorance, which is a primary obstacle to divine union.
The impulse of the vital being to possess, enjoy, or control, rooted in a sense of lack and separation.
The core method of Integral Yoga, combining and transforming the traditional paths of Jnana (Knowledge), Karma (Works), and Bhakti (Love/Devotion).
The path of realizing the Divine through purification and expansion of consciousness, discrimination, and meditation.
The path of offering all life-activities to the Divine, acting without desire for fruits, as an instrument of the Divine Will.
The path of uniting with the Divine through the heart's aspiration, love, worship, and consecration of emotions.
The constant, ardent, and sincere call or will arising from the soul and heart for the Divine, Truth, and Transformation.
The active dismissal of all that is undivine or an obstacle: egoism, desire, falsehood, doubt, negative vital impulses.
The progressive offering of one's entire being and life to the Divine (specifically the Divine Mother), allowing Her to guide and transform.
The emergence of the Psychic Being to the forefront, purifying and orienting the mind, vital, and physical towards the Divine.
The ascent of consciousness to higher spiritual planes (Higher Mind, Illumined Mind, Intuition, Overmind) and the descent of their powers into the being.
The ultimate stage: the descent and establishment of the Supermind, leading to a radical transformation of the entire being into a divine nature.
A deep, unshakable inner quietude and stillness, independent of outer circumstances; a basis for higher consciousness.
A state of mental and vital stability that is not easily disturbed by impacts or internal movements.
Maintaining an inner equanimity and poise in the face of all dualities: pleasure/pain, success/failure, honor/dishonor.
A dynamic inner certitude and trust in the Divine, the Divine Grace, and the truth of the spiritual path.
The compassionate intervention and power of the Divine that helps, guides, protects, and transforms the sadhaka.
The intense, pure, and self-giving love for and from the Divine; a powerful force for union and transformation.
The essential Reality beyond appearances; the divine Law (Rita) governing existence. Living in Truth is a core aim.
An integral and transparent alignment of all parts of the being with the central aspiration for the Divine and Truth.
The process of purifying the mind, silencing its habitual chatter, and opening it to higher levels of consciousness and illumination.
The purification and conversion of the life-energy (prana), desires, emotions, and impulses into a dynamic force for the Divine.
The most difficult part: making the physical consciousness and even the body receptive to and an expression of the Divine Light and Force.
The part of the being below waking consciousness, storing past impressions, habits, and obscure forces that resist transformation.
The ultimate basis of Matter, appearing as a total absence of Consciousness, yet holding the Divine involved within it.
Challenges, resistances, and attacks encountered in sadhana, viewed as tests and opportunities for strengthening aspiration and purification.
Universal forces that oppose the divine manifestation and seek to maintain ignorance, falsehood, and suffering.
The Mahashakti, the Consciousness-Force of the Divine, who carries out the Yoga and transformation in the sadhaka.
The formulator of Integral Yoga, providing the vision, knowledge, and force for the supramental manifestation.
Performing all actions, regardless of their nature, as a consecrated offering to the Divine, without attachment to results.
Practices of focused attention, mental silence, and inner contemplation to quiet the mind and open to higher states of consciousness.
Developing a detached awareness of one's thoughts, feelings, and impulses without identifying with them.
Not just absence of outer noise, but a profound mental and vital stillness, essential for receiving higher guidance and force.
Maintaining a constant state of self-awareness and alertness to discern and reject wrong movements or suggestions.
The quality of sustained effort and unwavering will in the face of difficulties, delays, or apparent failures in sadhana.
A heartfelt recognition and appreciation for the Divine's constant help, grace, and guidance in all circumstances.
The understanding that the individual self is nothing without the Divine; an absence of egoistic pride and self-assertion.
The individual who has achieved supramental transformation, living a life of truth, unity, and divine consciousness on Earth.
The ultimate aim for the physical: a body transformed by the Supramental Force, free from disease, decay, and death, capable of expressing divine qualities.
The harmonious perfection of all parts of the being – mental, vital, physical, psychic – around the divine center.
The understanding that individual sadhana contributes to a larger, collective spiritual evolution and the transformation of Earth-consciousness.
The international township founded by The Mother as a place for collective experimentation in actualizing human unity and a divine life.
A plane of consciousness above the ordinary thinking mind, characterized by global thought, conceptual spiritual knowledge, and direct ideation.
A plane of consciousness above Higher Mind, characterized by an influx of spiritual light, direct vision, and truth-seeing through illumination.
A plane of consciousness above Illumined Mind, characterized by direct, intimate contact with truth through flashes of intuitive knowledge and revelatory insight.
The highest plane of the mental hemisphere, a global consciousness of cosmic gods and forces, capable of holding multiple truths in harmony; the gateway to the Supermind.
The plane of consciousness closest to the material, forming a subtle-physical body that underlies and supports the gross physical form.
The essential vital being, when purified from desire and ego, becomes a powerful, dynamic instrument of the Divine Will and Life-Force.
The essential mental being, when stilled and purified, becomes a channel for higher knowledge, intuition, and silent spiritual thought.
The essential physical consciousness, when opened and transformed, becomes a stable, receptive, and conscious basis for divine manifestation.
The aspect of the Divine that is beyond all creation, manifestation, and individual or cosmic consciousness; the ultimate Unmanifest.
The aspect of the Divine that is immanent in and pervades the entire cosmos, as the Self and Spirit of all beings and things.
The aspect of the Divine that is present as the inmost Self (Atman) and evolving soul (Psychic Being) within each individual.
The dynamic Consciousness-Force or Power of the Divine, the executive energy that creates, sustains, and transforms the universe and carries out the Yoga.
The concept of the universe as a divine 'play' or 'sport' of the Absolute, an expression of its infinite potentialities and delight.
The philosophical understanding that the ultimate Reality is One, yet manifests as the diverse Many, without losing its essential unity.
The dual aspect of the Divine as the conscious Lord (Ishwara) and His inherent dynamic Power (Shakti), inseparable in manifestation.
The two aspects of Brahman: the static, silent, immutable Self (Akshara Brahman) and the dynamic, active, creative Power (Kshara Brahman or Shakti).
The state of being receptive and open to the Divine Influence, Light, Force, and Grace, allowing it to work within the being.
The capacity of the mind, vital, and physical nature to be malleable and adaptable to the workings of the Divine Force for transformation.
The spiritual capacity to remain steadfast and persevere through prolonged difficulties, pressures, and ordeals in sadhana.
The quality of calm waiting and trust in the Divine's timing and process, without anxiety or impatience for results.
The strength and fearlessness to face inner resistances (ego, desire) and outer oppositions or hostile forces on the spiritual path.
The act of offering all parts of one's being—thoughts, feelings, actions, will—to the Divine without reservation or demand.
The methodical practice of dedicating every movement, activity, and part of the being to the Divine, making life itself a Yoga.
The process of cleansing the mind-stuff (chitta) of impurities like egoism, desire, attachments, and negative emotions to make it fit for spiritual realization.
The practice of fixing the mind on a single point or object of concentration, a key preliminary for meditation.
In Patanjali's Yoga, the combined practice of Dharana (concentration), Dhyana (meditation), and Samadhi (absorption) on a single object.
The state of being free from attachment to worldly objects, outcomes, or egoistic desires; a key aspect of Vairagya.
Cultivating the stance of a detached observer (Sakshi) of one's own thoughts, emotions, and actions without identifying with them.
The 'Indweller' or 'Inner Controller'; the Divine presence within that guides the soul from within, often felt through the Psychic Being.
The ultimate intention and dynamic action of the Divine in the cosmos and in the individual; aligning one's personal will with it is a key to Yoga.
Understanding that spiritual progress is often not linear but involves periods of ascent, descent, assimilation, and overcoming obstacles.
The nature of various spiritual experiences, their role in sadhana, how to validate them, and potential pitfalls like ego-inflation or misinterpretation.
A deeper look into common obstacles in Integral Yoga, such as inertia, doubt, vital revolt, mental rigidity, and external difficulties.
The dual process in Integral Yoga: the ascent of individual consciousness to higher planes and the descent of Divine Consciousness and Force to transform the lower nature.
The detailed process of the Psychic Being coming forward to influence and govern the mind, life, and body, infusing them with its qualities.
The process by which the being is infused with the peace, light, power, and vastness of the higher spiritual planes of consciousness.
The ultimate transformation where the Supramental Truth-Consciousness descends and acts directly to divinize the entire mental, vital, and physical nature.
Sri Aurobindo's analysis of the seven fundamental forms of cosmic and individual ignorance that Integral Yoga seeks to overcome.
The fundamental knots of ego, desire, and ignorance that bind the soul to the lower nature and prevent divine realization.
Practical methods and stages in the dissolution of the ego-sense, a central aim of Integral Yoga.
The conversion of the vital being's desires and impulses from egoistic cravings into a consecrated force for the Divine.
The consciousness inherent in the physical body itself, its habits, inertia, and its potential for transformation and receptivity to spiritual force.
The Mother's exploration of a yoga acting directly on the consciousness within the cells of the body for radical physical transformation.
Understanding and utilizing the states of sleep and dream from a yogic perspective for inner exploration and progress.
The Integral Yoga perspective on death as a transition, the soul's journey after leaving the body, and the process of rebirth.
Sri Aurobindo's principal philosophical work, elaborating the metaphysical foundations, evolutionary vision, and transformative goal of Integral Yoga.
Sri Aurobindo's comprehensive exposition of the methods and principles of Integral Yoga, detailing the paths of Works, Knowledge, Love, and Self-Perfection.
Sri Aurobindo's epic spiritual poem, a symbolic narrative of the human soul's journey and the conquest of death by divine love and power.
A 13-volume record of The Mother's conversations, chronicling her experiences in the yoga of cellular transformation and the supramental descent.
The vision of a future humanity transformed by the Supermind, a 'gnostic race' living a divine life of truth, harmony, and unity on Earth.
The central theme of an ongoing evolution of consciousness in the cosmos and in the individual, from inconscience towards the Supermind.
Principles of education based on Integral Yoga, aiming for the harmonious and integral development of all parts of the being: physical, vital, mental, psychic, and spiritual.
